pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: I made a gearbox joint with the default axis values and the model exploded. Then I made one with parallel axes (same xyz) and the model exploded after a few seconds. What are good values and should we fill them in by default?
content.html: I made a gearbox joint with the default axis values and the model exploded. Then I made one with parallel axes (same xyz) and the model exploded after a few seconds. What are good values and should we fill them in by default?

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: I think it's going to be difficult to give default values with our current gearbox joint implementation. I managed to use the editor to create something like the [gearbox.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/test/worlds/gearbox.world). I used a third link as the reference body, and gearbox joint has two unit z axes
content.html: I think it's going to be difficult to give default values with our current gearbox joint implementation. I managed to use the editor to create something like the gearbox.world. I used a third link as the reference body, and gearbox joint has two unit z axes

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: Is a reference body required for a gearbox joint?
content.html: Is a reference body required for a gearbox joint?

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: yes I think so, it's set here in [ODEGearboxJoint](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/04c8460a5b855f9719c0cc306adf43f79064ed6a/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEGearboxJoint.cc#ODEGearboxJoint.cc-74) and used in ode [calculations](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/04c8460a5b855f9719c0cc306adf43f79064ed6a/deps/opende/src/joints/gearbox.cpp#gearbox.cpp-69).
content.html: yes I think so, it's set here in ODEGearboxJoint and used in ode calculations.

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: Does it make sense to set a default reference body?
content.html: Does it make sense to set a default reference body?

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw:
I've only been able to make it work by setting a reference body that's not the parent or child link of the joint. So we would not be able to set them as the default reference body. The user would need to insert a third link and set that as the reference body. 

I'll try again and confirm this.
content.html:
I've only been able to make it work by setting a reference body that's not the parent or child link of the joint. So we would not be able to set them as the default reference body. The user would need to insert a third link and set that as the reference body.

I'll try again and confirm this.

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: Sounds good.
content.html: Sounds good.

content.html: The test uses the parent as the reference body, should we change this?

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: updated test, 3f65309
content.html: updated test, 3f65309

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw:
findings:

1. empty reference body: links rotate but eventually goes out of control

2. joint child link or parent link set as reference body: same as 1.

3. a third link set as reference body (a link whose pose is not affected by the rotation of parent and child link): links rotate as expected

So I think 3. works best as least in my test setup. I left reference body empty as default in the inspector and it's up to the user to specify it.
content.html:
findings:

  1. empty reference body: links rotate but eventually goes out of control

  2. joint child link or parent link set as reference body: same as 1.

  3. a third link set as reference body (a link whose pose is not affected by the rotation of parent and child link): links rotate as expected

So I think 3. works best as least in my test setup. I left reference body empty as default in the inspector and it's up to the user to specify it.

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.html:
How about this:

message Gearbox
{
  required string reference_body = 1;
  required double ratio                 = 2;
  required double thread_pitch    = 3;
}

optional Gearbox gearbox = 20;

This way, the parameters for a gearbox are required if the gearbox is used.

content.html: I think thread pitch is for screw joints.

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: Perhaps we should think of a way to visualize the reference body in the editor. Right now the hotspot connects parent and child, and there's a line from the child to the joint. Do you think it makes sense to open an issue for this?
content.html: Perhaps we should think of a way to visualize the reference body in the editor. Right now the hotspot connects parent and child, and there's a line from the child to the joint. Do you think it makes sense to open an issue for this?

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: Actually, maybe even the axes visualization might be misleading right now. If I understand well,  each axis is attached to a different body, right? So the most common case is probably to have them parallel but not coincident, right?
content.html: Actually, maybe even the axes visualization might be misleading right now. If I understand well, each axis is attached to a different body, right? So the most common case is probably to have them parallel but not coincident, right?

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: yes axis1 is for child link and axis2 is for parent link. Maybe we need to have a special check in JointVisual and visualize the axes differently for this joint type - ticketed issue #1679
content.html: yes axis1 is for child link and axis2 is for parent link. Maybe we need to have a special check in JointVisual and visualize the axes differently for this joint type - ticketed issue #1679

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: I think it doesn't make sense to have params like cfm, bounce, etc for fixed joints, right? In fact, maybe even pose isn't necessary?
content.html: I think it doesn't make sense to have params like cfm, bounce, etc for fixed joints, right? In fact, maybe even pose isn't necessary?

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: I think most won't be needed but need to confirm this. Not sure if we could still set params like setting cfm and erp to have softer constraints on fixed joints for better simulation stability? @scpeters
content.html: I think most won't be needed but need to confirm this. Not sure if we could still set params like setting cfm and erp to have softer constraints on fixed joints for better simulation stability? @scpeters

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw:
Your comment just made me realized that I did not properly implement the `SetParam` method for fixed joints in maximal coordinates engines (ODE and Bullet). 

For ODE, the `dJointSetFixedParam` should have been used to expose cfm and erp.
content.html:
Your comment just made me realized that I did not properly implement the SetParam method for fixed joints in maximal coordinates engines (ODE and Bullet).

For ODE, the dJointSetFixedParam should have been used to expose cfm and erp.

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: thanks, good to know. I've ticketed issue #1684 to keep track of this
content.html: thanks, good to know. I've ticketed issue #1684 to keep track of this

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw: thanks, I've been away for a few days. The `erp` and `cfm` parameters are definitely relevant for fixed joints. The issue looks good.
content.html: thanks, I've been away for a few days. The erp and cfm parameters are definitely relevant for fixed joints. The issue looks good.

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor

content.raw:
For simulation of Six Axis Force/Torque Sensor using fixed joints the pose information is important, because
the joint origin is the point with respect to which the measured torque is expressed. Using the sensor pose
it is possible to change the orientation frame with respect to which the force and the torque are expressed, 
but the point is hardcoded to be the origin of the joint frame.
content.html: For simulation of Six Axis Force/Torque Sensor using fixed joints the pose information is important, because the joint origin is the point with respect to which the measured torque is expressed. Using the sensor pose it is possible to change the orientation frame with respect to which the force and the torque are expressed, but the point is hardcoded to be the origin of the joint frame.

pullrequest.title: Support more joint types in model editor
